docs.lead_paragraph: I am a yoga teacher seeking certification from a national yoga association, a rigorous process that includes demonstrating poses and teaching them to students. I am also pregnant. Until recently, pregnant women could be tested, performing modified poses, but now there is a new policy: ''You must not be pregnant at the time of the assessment, out of consideration for your own health and that of your unborn child.'' Doesn't this unethically penalize women? Anonymous This policy unfairly thwarts people capable of performing a task, and because it necessarily refers only to women rather than defining a general level of physical ability, it is doubly unethical.

headline.kicker: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 8-21-05: THE ETHICIST

docs.snippet: "I am a yoga teacher seeking certification from a national yoga association, a rigorous process that includes demonstrating poses and teaching them to students. I am also pregnant. ..."

docs.lead_paragraph: IN 2001, President Bush restricted federal financing for stem cell research. The decision, which was shaped at least partly by the Republican Party's evangelical Christian base, and which disappointed many American scientists and businessmen, provoked joy in India. The weekly newsmagazine India Today, read mostly by the country's ambitious middle class, spoke of a ''new pot of gold'' for Indian science and businesses. ''If Indians are smart,'' the magazine said, American qualms about stem cell research ''can open an opportunity to march ahead.'' Just four years later, this seems to have occurred. According to Ernst & Young's Global Biotechnology Report in 2004, Indian biotechnology companies are expected to grow tenfold in the next five years, creating more than a million jobs. With more than 10,000 highly trained and cheaply available scientists, the country is one of the leading biotechnology powers along with Korea, Singapore, China, Japan, Sweden, Britain and Israel.

headline.main: IDEAS & TRENDS: Perspective; How India Reconciles Hindu Values And Biotech

docs.snippet: Scientists in India find few religious restraints on their work. But what would Gandhi do?
docs.section_name: Technology; Science; Health; Week in Review

docs.lead_paragraph: MY desire to have a fourth child waxed and waned. On the one hand, my children were begging me for a younger sister or brother. My husband and I each come from families of four, and having any fewer didn't feel right (as if having a child was a matter of balancing some equation). Also, I loved being a mother. I thought of having another child as akin to gaining a big bag of gold. Sure, it would be heavy, but who could say no to riches? On the other hand, my body was tired. I had passed 40. Like a car with high mileage, still functioning, but for how long? Next year, my youngest would be in school until 2 p.m., and finally I'd have time to finish my first novel, make some money and get rid of all that baby paraphernalia in a garage sale. So there I was, stuck between two desires.

docs.lead_paragraph: NATE FISHER is dead, and the Peabody Award-winning series that gave birth to him, ''Six Feet Under,'' ends its five-season run on HBO tonight. Alan Ball, the show's creator, acknowledges that some things in the series finale, which he wrote and directed, may be unexpected. But the Fishers won't be facing anything sheerly for the sake of surprise. ''They're really going to confront their grief,'' Mr. Ball (right) said in a telephone interview from a California gym where he was trying to ''undo the damage'' of nine months of sedentary work and junk food in the writers' room.
docs.snippet: NATE FISHER is dead, and the Peabody Award-winning series that gave birth to him, ''Six Feet Under,'' ends its five-season run on HBO tonight. Alan Ball, the show's creator, acknowledges that some things in the series finale, which he wrote and...

docs.lead_paragraph: JENNIFER CALISE, a young woman who is expecting twins by a surrogate in March, was grateful to have Melanie McGuire in her life. Ms. McGuire was more than a skilled nurse at a top fertility clinic in New Jersey that Ms. Calise had turned to in her struggle to have a child; she was also a trusted ally, a sympathetic confidant and a steady hand, speaking to Ms. Calise almost daily over many months as she guided her past the emotional troughs that are inevitable when a woman allows another to carry and deliver her child. In the evolving world of fertility treatments, hers was a rarefied role, that of a kind of emotional midwife.
docs.snippet: The clients of a fertility clinic in New Jersey are struggling with two radically different images of a trusted nurse.

docs.lead_paragraph: While suggesting that its decision might seem ''callous and unfeeling,'' a federal appeals court here ruled Thursday that the Navy need not pay for an abortion received by a sailor's wife, even though doctors said the fetus had a birth defect and could not survive. The unanimous ruling by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit came in the case of a 23-year-old woman who lives in Bremerton, Wash. Her name was not disclosed.

headline.main: Court Rules U.S. Need Not Pay For Abortion of Doomed Fetus

docs.snippet: A federal appeals court ruled that the Navy need not pay for an abortion received by a sailor's wife, even though doctors said the fetus could not survive.

docs.lead_paragraph: Any woman who has ever rooted around the laundry pile in a desperate search for clean tights has had a Bridget Jones moment. Now, 10 years after Helen Fielding created Bridget -- witty, flawed, embarrassingly easy to identify with -- the character has returned to her origins in a new ''Bridget Jones's Diary'' column. (It appears every Thursday online and in print in The Independent of London.) In the decade since the original ''Bridget Jones'' column appeared, though, we have seen much more than the two Bridget novels that followed. ''Sex and the City'' has come and gone, its heroines wisely heading offstage before they turned into little old ladies tottering in their Jimmy Choos. The chick-lit trend, which the ''Bridget Jones'' novels helped spawn, has arrived, exploded and grown tiresome. Bridget now has the movie-star face of Renée Zellweger (plumped-out, but still a movie-star face), while the men in her life -- the caddish Daniel Cleaver and her knight-in-emotional-armor, Mark Darcy -- have become Hugh Grant and Colin Firth.

headline.main: Dear Diary, Time to Catch Up: Same Men (Cads), No Baby (Alas)

docs.abstract: Caryn James Critic's Notebook column on Helen Fielding's new Bridget Jones's Diary column that appears weekly online as well as in print in the Independent of London; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Ten years after Helen Fielding created Bridget Jones, the character has returned to her origins in a newspaper column.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE world knows that Africans bear the brunt of the AIDS pandemic and that nearly two-thirds of the people infected with H.I.V. live here. The disease is devastating households and crippling economies across the continent. Though data show that girls and women are far more vulnerable to infection than men, we have yet to summon the courage and the political will to empower and protect them. In Nigeria, and across sub-Saharan Africa and the Caribbean, epidemics are already feminized. For example, nearly 58 percent of Nigerians with H.I.V. are female. What's more, in virtually every region of the world, infections among girls and women are rising sharply.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Babatunde Osotimehin says Africans bear brunt of AIDS pandemic, and data show that girls and women are far more vulnerable to infection than men; says protecting women and girls from AIDS requires true and effective partnership with international donors who are willing to undertake honest, open dialogue about what works in each country; notes United States government, a major donor partner, promotes abstinence until marriage as main way to avoid HIV infection, but in Nigeria, girls and women typically cannot negotiate when, where or with whom they have sex; says it is vital that development partners not impose their ideological or political views as condition of partnership (M)
docs.snippet: Though women and girls are far more vulnerable to H.I.V. infection than men, we have yet to summon the courage to protect them.
